references: In this section, we demonstrate the effectiveness of
-FL in handling heterogeneity in federated learning. Our experiments were implemented in Python using automatic differentiation provided by PyTorch while the data was preprocessed using LEAF

.
The code to reproduce our experiments can be found online.
We start by describing the datasets, tasks, and models in

.
We present numerical comparisons to several recent works – we list them in
and show the experimental results in
-FL provides the most favorable tradeoff between average error and the error on tail clients in

.
Finally, we numerically study the privacy-utility tradeoff of the differentially private quantile computation (in
Full details regarding the experiments, as well as additional results, are provided in the supplementary material.

S7.T4.caption:
Table 4: 
Misclassification error % of FedAvg and ΔΔ\Delta-FL with model personalization on the EMNIST ConvNet model.
Each table entry is the average
over 555 random seeds, while the subscript denotes the standard deviation. The boldfaced entries indicate the smallest error in each column.
references: We now repeat the experiment of
with model personalization for the EMNIST ConvNet model.
We personalize a model to a test client by finetuning a model trained either via FedAvg or
-FL on the particular test client’s data at the end of federated training. This simple baseline is competitive with more sophisticated personalization algorithms

.
Towards this end, we split the data on each test client into a training set used for the finetuning and a test set used to report the evaluation metrics.
We finetune the model for
epochs with the same local learning rate as at the end of federated training.
The numerical results are given in
. We observe that after model personalization, both FedAvg and
-FL models perform similarly, often within one standard deviation of each other. The mean error is marginally smaller for FedAvg while the
percentile error is marginally smaller for
percentage points, is smaller than the standard deviation,

number of communication rounds.

for linear models was tuned with cross validation from the set
. This was performed as described below.

For each dataset, we held out half the training clients as validation clients. Then, for different values of the regularization parameter,
we trained a model with the (smaller subset of) training clients and evaluate its performance on the validation clients.
We selected the value of the regularization parameter
as the one which gave the smallest
percentile of the misclassification error on the validation clients.

client losses are available to the server.
